[b] Title: Daft Punk's Groovy Game Review: Beatbuddy Tales of the Guardians

[INT. DAFT PUNK'S FUTURISTIC STUDIO - NIGHT]

ü§ñ1 (Thomas): (adjusting helmet) Alright, Daft Punk here, and today, we're diving into Beatbuddy: Tales of the Guardians!

ü§ñ2 (Guy-Manuel): (nodding) That's right, Thomas. A game that claims to fuse action-adventure with beats. Let's see if it's as funky as they say.

[DAFT PUNK STARTS THE GAME]

ü§ñ1: (excitedly) Woah, check out those hand-painted visuals! It's like we're in a disco ball's dream.

ü§ñ2: (grooving) The colors, man. So vivid. It's like playing inside one of our music videos.

[BEATBUDDY APPEARS ON SCREEN]

ü§ñ1: (raising robotic eyebrow) Look at this little beat-making creature. He's got moves!

ü§ñ2: (nudging) Beats by Beatbuddy. I like it.

[GAMEPLAY BEGINS]

ü§ñ1: (tapping foot) Okay, he's interacting with the environment to the beat. That's pretty slick.

ü§ñ2: (air-drumming) I could remix this into a killer track.

[EXCLUSIVE SOUNDTRACK KICKS IN]

ü§ñ1: (bobbing head) Austin Wintory, Parov Stelar, Sabrepulse ‚Äì these beats are top-notch.

ü§ñ2: (pointing) Look at Clef over there. He's the comic relief. Bet he's got some jokes as funky as our helmets.

[CLEF'S JOKES ON SCREEN]

ü§ñ1: (laughing) Clef, you sly note! These jokes are cracking me up.

ü§ñ2: (groovy voice) Comedy level: disco ball.

[LEVEL TRANSITION]

ü§ñ1: (amazed) Each level is a hand-painted masterpiece. It's like we're wandering through a futuristic art gallery.

ü§ñ2: (twirling invisible mustache) Prince Maestro is the bad guy? I bet his beats are out of tune.

[GAME INTENSIFIES]

ü§ñ1: (getting into it) Dodging obstacles, solving puzzles ‚Äì Beatbuddy's a rhythm master.

ü§ñ2: (slamming buttons) I feel like I'm in a Daft Punk concert, but with more puzzles.

[FINAL BOSS APPEARS]

ü§ñ1: (serious) Here comes the showdown with Prince Maestro.

ü§ñ2: (pumping fists) Let's drop the bass and defeat this villain!

[VICTORY SCREEN]

ü§ñ1: (victorious) We did it! Beatbuddy and his sisters saved the day!

ü§ñ2: (high-fiving virtually) That was one groovy journey.

[ENDING SCREEN]

ü§ñ1: (leaning back) Final thoughts?

ü§ñ2: (smirking) Beatbuddy: Tales of the Guardians ‚Äì a game that makes you move, groove, and laugh. It's like a dance party for your console.

ü§ñ1: (nodding) Definitely worth adding to the Daft Punk gaming playlist.

[DAFT PUNK LOGS OUT]

ü§ñ2: (whispering) Now, let's get back to working on our next hit.

[FADE OUT WITH DAFT PUNK'S SIGNATURE SYNTH]

üéµü§ñü§ñüéµ [/b]

[b] **Title: Winds of Groovy Destruction Review: Beatbuddy vs. The Guardians**

[INT. MEMES OF LIBERTY - NIGHT]

üó°Ô∏è Raiden: (cracking knuckles) Alright, time to review a game. Beatbuddy: Tales of the Guardians, here we go.

üí™ Senator Armstrong: (flexing muscles) Let's make this review as strong as my nanomachines.

[THE WINDS OF DESTRUCTION ENTER]

üå™Ô∏è Mistral: (playfully twirling her winds) Hey there, boys. Ready for a breezy review?

üî• Monsoon: (surrounded by flames) The heat is on. Let's spice it up.

‚ö° Sundowner: (cracking electrified knuckles) Shocking revelations, I hope.

üåä Bladewolf: (barking in binary) Woof, let's byte into this game.

üó°Ô∏è Jetstream Sam: (elegantly unsheathing sword) Apologies for the entrance, gentlemen. I'm here for the slicing critique.

[BEATBUDDY GAMEPLAY STARTS]

üó°Ô∏è Raiden: (watching the hand-painted levels) These visuals are sharper than my HF Blade. It's like I'm in the VR mission of a high-tech ninja.

üí™ Senator Armstrong: (stroking his beard) It's like an art exhibition in cyberspace. Reminds me of the good ol' days of war.

[BEATBUDDY APPEARS]

üî• Monsoon: (smirking) Beatbuddy's got moves, huh? Let's see if he can dance with the winds. Maybe he'll join the Winds of Destruction fan club.

‚öîÔ∏è Jetstream Sam: (nodding) A rhythm game, you say? Interesting. I shall evaluate its blade-worthiness.

[EXCLUSIVE SOUNDTRACK PLAYS]

‚ö° Sundowner: (headbanging) Now that's what I call an INVINCIBLE soundtrack! *Nanomachines, son!* I mean, *Metal Beat*.

üå™Ô∏è Mistral: (creating a wind symphony) Austin Wintory and crew did a bang-up job with these beats. It's almost as beautiful as the sound of slicing through cyborgs.

[CLEF'S JOKES APPEAR]

üåä Bladewolf: (processing humor.exe) Clef's jokes are making my circuits laugh. It's like the Codec calls, but with more rhythm.

üó°Ô∏è Raiden: (nudging Senator Armstrong) Even more entertaining than a political debate. Maybe we should recruit Clef for Desperado Enforcement.

[LEVEL TRANSITION]

üí™ Senator Armstrong: (adjusting sunglasses) These hand-painted levels are a visual feast. It's like the VR missions on a psychedelic drug.

üî• Monsoon: (emitting flames) The colors are hotter than my fiery temperament. It's like I'm back on the African battlefield.

[GAME INTENSIFIES]

‚ö° Sundowner: (unleashing electric attacks) Dodging obstacles and solving puzzles. Beatbuddy's got some skills. Reminds me of dodging Blade Wolf's bites.

üå™Ô∏è Mistral: (twirling with enthusiasm) This game's got the rhythm of a thousand winds. Just like my L'Etranger's dance.

üó°Ô∏è Jetstream Sam: (elegantly slicing through enemies) The gameplay has finesse, much like my katana techniques. I shall cut through this review with grace.

[FINAL BOSS APPEARS]

üî• Monsoon: (raising fiery eyebrows) Prince Maestro, huh? Time to bring the heat. I hope he's as tough as Jetstream Sam.

‚öîÔ∏è Jetstream Sam: (readying sword) I shall handle this, gentlemen. Stand back.

[BEATBUDDY DEFEATS PRINCE MAESTRO]

üåä Bladewolf: (barking in binary) Victory confirmed. Good job, Beatbuddy. Reminds me of when I took down Jetstream Sam.

[ENDING SCREEN]

üí™ Senator Armstrong: (leaning back) Final thoughts, everyone?

‚ö° Sundowner: (smirking) Beatbuddy: Tales of the Guardians ‚Äì it's electrifying, visually stunning, and a musical joyride. It's like fighting Metal Gear Excelsus, but with more rhythm.

üå™Ô∏è Mistral: (blowing a playful breeze) Couldn't have said it better myself. This game's as refreshing as a Mistral wind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044340549', 'num_games_owned': 184, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1703914619}
review:
Played up until about half way through the penultimate level (act?) until I finally let myself acknowledge I wasn't enjoying it and there was no reason to force myself to finish. I found navigating the world to be a chore, whether solo or in the ship, and the story wasn't really interesting enough to keep me going. It also didn't help that at least once a play session, the ship would bug out and I couldn't fire the turret unless I quit and restarted the game. To its credit, the music is good (just very loud) and it has a nice look.

(Also the way they structure the collectible system is a major pet peeve of mine. Literally hundreds of gems scattered through each level and unless you find every single, you get nothing. Again, there are hundreds of them!)

author: {'steamid': '76561197993416727', 'num_games_owned': 575, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1537659835}
review: Beatbuddy is a 2D musical adventure that immerses the player in a vibrant underwater world. The gameplay revolves around synchronizing the movement of the protagonist, Beat, with the rhythm of the environment, which allows him to overcome enemies and obstacles. The game features hand-drawn backgrounds, colorful characters, and a catchy soundtrack composed by various artists. Beatbuddy is a unique and enjoyable experience that blends pumping music, art, and action in creative ways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022429977', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1388423965}
review: Beatbuddy: Tale of the Guardians is an enchanting and innovative adventure that beautifully blends music and gameplay. Set in a vibrant underwater world, the game's unique art style and visually stunning environments are a feast for the eyes. What truly sets Beatbuddy apart is its integration of music into every aspect of the gameplay. Each level is designed around a captivating soundtrack that not only enhances the atmosphere but also plays a key role in puzzle-solving and navigation. The rhythm-based gameplay is both intuitive and invigorating, ensuring that players are constantly engaged. Beatbuddy is not just a game; it's a harmonious journey that celebrates the power of music in a most interactive and delightful way.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971288866', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1699398794}
review: Boring, irritating narrator reading notes, badly feeling controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561198402588414', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 236, 'playtime_forever': 300, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 300, 'last_played': 1698272167}
review: Beatbuddy: Tale of the Guardians, while showcasing promising elements, ultimately falls short of being a satisfactory gaming experience. Its inherent flaws become glaringly apparent during the final level, rendering it impossible to complete. This game-breaking issue in the last sequence is not just a minor inconvenience but a debilitating technical error, and regrettably, no amount of reloading or level restarts can remedy it. Despite being a decade-old title, Beatbuddy has proven incapable of enduring the test of time, a testament to the abandonment it has suffered at the hands of its development team.

review:

Le fait est qu'il met en avant son c√¥t√© rythmique bas√© sur la musique etc, sauf que dans les faits il se rapprochera plus d'un plateformeur genre 'Shiny The Firefly' ou plus des niveaux aquatiques d'un Rayman Legends par exemple avec une partie plus puzzle & avec des 'bumper' o√π l'on rebondira automatiquement...

author: {'steamid': '76561198091309187', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1272, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 514, 'last_played': 1693598513}
review:
Look, I bought this game years ago and I only now managed to finish it. The music and the visuals are stellar, but everything else is so janky. As mentioned, I only finished this game a couple of years later, since it was just so frustrating to play. The environment has so many corners, that it makes the character stuck on edges and killed by the timed animals in the area. So many broken textures. There are even broken textures in the credits?! Some parts of the map were straight up missing for me. Some of the plants and creatures can be 'turned off' by hitting switches, but would revert back after you finish a level, but when I would move on to the next stage the creatures would still be turned off and I couldn't get though the game. I was stuck in so many areas and re-starting from last checkpoint wouldn't change a thing, so you would need to re-start the whole stage over and over, which lost me a lot of progress.
Like I said, this game had so much going for it, but if only the developers would come back to fix the game so it is actually playable, then it would be a upvote no question.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971544967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 148, 'playtime_forever': 577, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 577, 'last_played': 1683942476}
review:
A bit hard to describe, but kind of a 2D, puzzle platformer, rhythm game without the platforms taking place underwater.  I guess the game had a story but not sure what it was other than save your sister from the bad guy.  The game has two locomotion types, one where you swim and another where you pilot a submarine type of vessel.  You do not choose these modes, they are dictated by the level.  More of the game is swimming, and that also has more of the puzzles as you can interact with the world more.  The sub hops to the beat when moving and can shoot and regenerate so those areas tend to be easier and quicker.  The puzzles are pretty straightforward and mainly consist of setting up some bouncers so you can destroy obstacles and timing based sequences where you need to carry power to a new source while dodging dangerous environments and enemies.  There are some other interesting things going on like perspective changing devices but these mostly felt like a novelty.  The rhythm aspect, in terms of gameplay, is kind of limited and can largely be ignored and just helps you avoid damage if you time things right.

The game has it's good points, mainly in the presentation and music.  Nice 2D graphics, great animation and a soundtrack that all the enemies pulse to.  The gameplay itself is somewhat fun, but nothing to get excited about.

Negatives would mainly be the movement (playing with the mouse).  Your character is swimming and has a certain momentum, which makes stopping where you want pretty tough sometimes.  Unfortunately the game will often require you to stop to avoid bullets or whatnot, which is awkward.  Also it is controlled by where your mouse cursor is currently positioned.  That's fine but sometimes you just lose track of where it is and have trouble going where you want.  Normally it's not a big deal but you will often be required to do some precise movements, especially late in the game, and this can be frustrating.  Some of the late game puzzles/challenges also were not so fun like a big maze you need to move walls around for with little direction.  Fun at first, but became tedious and wasn't helped by having to it twice as I was supposed to kill all the enemies in there but was never told that.  Also there are places in the game where you can get stuck or triggers fail to happen and have to restart the level (luckily you can).  Happened to me once and saw others mention it for other areas.  Beyond that, the puzzles are all pretty simple.  The only tough aspects are sometimes figuring out what you are supposed to do, where you are supposed to go or just getting there fast enough.

Overall, the game is fine but not my cup of tea.  If you are looking for something to occupy a handful of hours, it fits the bill but likely won't be anything you remember for very long unless you really love the music.

author: {'steamid': '76561198097775066', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 364, 'last_played': 1669409793}
review:
The game is very focused on music and pressing buttons to the beat of the background music. 
The puzzles are simplistic and sometimes more tedious than they are fun or challenging. 
There are a few timed passages which are purely frustrating to try over and over again only to fail because you messed up one button press and got out of rhythm briefly. 

I found the controlls a bit too unreliable for the game to really be a fun experience

author: {'steamid': '76561198003117833', 'num_games_owned': 1192, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1670714863}
review:
I realised I have 1100+ games in my Steam library and I was going to die before I played them all.

So thought I'd spend a bit of time on each one, a new one every night, and leave a short initial review.

Beautiful art style, simple game play, nice music. Just a bit boring for me to keep my interest. Borderline vote - I wish I could vote neutral. If you like puzzling side scrolling platforming games, its likely for you, but not for me. 

OK, but not for me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050718401', 'num_games_owned': 673, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 352, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 352, 'last_played': 1573558254}
review:
Oh boy. I finished this game years ago. Might as well drop a review.

The music is great. This is where the good things I have to say about it end.

The main... 4ish tracks were excellent choices... but they get very repetitive. The puzzles were braindead and also repetitive. The writing was incredibly  boring to me. The first time I played this, I got a game breaking bug that made me drop the game for 5 years. Didn't get that the second time around fortunately.

But yeah, there are many other games that are so much better than this. It was a dreary experience. It was boring in almost all senses of the word

author: {'steamid': '76561198024953383', 'num_games_owned': 361, 'num_reviews': 160, 'playtime_forever': 165, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 165, 'last_played': 1517202266}
review:
I don't like steam's binary rating system, so don't read this as a hard "pass".
The game has a clever concept, and the electro swing music is great. It's got cute characters and story. But after a while, I just found it to be getting repetitive in terms of gameplay. 
I wanted to keep playing, but just got bored.
If you're looking for a casual cute music oriented game, this definitely is worth playing, but don't expect it to wow you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035606911', 'num_games_owned': 741, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 301, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 301, 'last_played': 1658962098}
review:
While this game does have some good things going for it, I felt like the premise of a puzzle game where you must act on the timing of a beat doesn't work with floaty underwater controls. None of the puzzles themselves were particular hard; the difficulty came from fighting with the controls which I found really annoying. 

The story also feels half-baked and the ending wasn't very satisfying. 

The art is great though and you might just enjoy the game if you enjoy the soundtrack (I did not)

author: {'steamid': '76561198096722442', 'num_games_owned': 1704, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 438, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1656862115}
review:
There's a lot of style in this game, and some of the core ideas are very solid. The problem is that the game doesn't do much with those ideas. The music is good, and everything moves to its beat, so going through the levels is a pleasant experience. But it's not a rhythm game, and it's not a good arcade / puzzle / adventure game either. The levels are a just a bit repetitive, the mechanics don't evolve much, and there's no gameplay climax at the end. On the positive side, it doesn't overstay its welcome. 

The rhythm aspect of the gameplay is limited to predicting patterns, like when a turret is going to stop shooting, based on the beats. This was a nice start, but at some point I was expecting to face a more sustained rhythmic challenge where I would need to consider the actions at every beat for a few consecutive musical bars, but the challenges just aren't built that way. 

I can't recommend against it because, as I said, it's a pleasant experience, but I was expecting more.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975960529', 'num_games_owned': 1441, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 311, 'last_played': 1656392884}
review:
This game started out fine, but then it got bogged down.
At first it was a fairly standard puzzle collectathon - but then numerous issues emerged.

First, the "enemies" - they're not really enemies - they're obstacles.  And yes, I realize that enemies typically are obstacles - but in this game that's pretty much all they are.  
You could take away the art and replace them with circles and you'd get fairly the same effect - they're just in the way, for the sake of being in the way.  I don't know if the developers thought they would be a "challenge" - but they're just maddening.  
In the beginning it's rare to see enemies - but then you get an "upgrade" later that essentially combines two of your abilities into one.  And they teach you how to use it in 
a training ground - but then they just swarm you with enemies almost immediately thereafter and it doesn't really matter that there's health orbs - the upgrade 
isn't that useful in that situation, you essentially have to time *running away* until you finally get it and are able to deal with it.

But that takes way too long, in a game with very diminishing returns.  Let's talk about the collectathon aspect for a moment.  You get introduced to the purple 
"shiny trinkets" early on and are told that they're good, for reasons. So if you've been trying to collect them, great.  Except for the stage design.

Since most people won't be following a guide directly, there are forks in the proverbial road.  So if you veer left and that's the way the game progresses,
too bad, so sad! You can't go back to get those purple collectables that you missed unless you restart the level.  And this game isn't good enough to restart 
a level.

All the trinkets do is open up a game dev gallery anyways, as far as I can tell.  And I don't care what happens if you get all of them.  That's the problem.
The game makes you not care.

Eventually vehicle sections are introduced, allowing the player to shoot certain enemies.  And while this is satisfying, it gets increasingly obnoxious when 
you realize that although you have limited ammo, your gun overheats - and the enemies respawn - meaning that unless you time it just right, you'll get hit
even though you should be able to shoot.  And be hit you will.  Over and over again, ping-ponging back and forth between enemies.  The slight saving grace
is that the ship auto-heals, but even that's not enough.  If the overheating was removed, it would be so much more pleasant to do the ship sections.
But again, I think that's the developer's idea of challenge - I call it a *slog*.

And I hope you like autoscrollers!  Because although the initial levels take a metroidvania-esque exploration aspect, the ship levels tend to be autoscrolling,
and there are some parts where you need to go in one direction very fast - regardless of the shiny trinkets you are missing - because again, you cannot go back.

The musical choices are also very strange.  I *know* that at least two, maybe three music tracks in this game have vocals.  But I couldn't tell you what the heck
the lyrics were, because although I checked (and all I found was a simple audio slider) for sound options, for some reason the backing music is so muted
I cannot hear the lyrics except in certain parts.

With all the forced "keep going" in the game, it tires you out and you lose caring about the plot.  You just want to finish the game to finish the game and move on,
those eight feared words, "I don't care what happens to these people" - or in this case, Symphonians?

The puzzles are mostly OK, but there was one and pretty much only one that was out of place, or at least I don't recall being taught the basics of the solution.
You have to grab a power generator that is opening a gate, and bounce around and then dash to get out of the gate that's closing with the generator.
However, since that was like the only one that did that, I kept trying (and failing) to take the generator with me through a red portal that will only transport
you.  Other than that one, the puzzles were fine.  And since there's a lot of puzzles, that's a good thing that didn't really add to the frustration.

The other big frustrating part was the health system.  Essentially, there's a health bar and you hit orbs to get health back.  But it's pretty pointless.
Checkpoints are generally pretty good in this game, so if you die, who cares.  But it does matter with these spiky things that you can temporarily disable.
It seems very odd that some of them are one hit kills and yet some of them aren't.  And when you try to get through them, very often the controls lead you
to getting caught on the side and then bam, one hit kill.  Or in the ship sections, bounced around enemies.  The controls of this game aren't the controls that
the game really should have shipped with - better tiny movement options would prevent the sticking that occurred with the enemies.  Also,
with the health, the only real reason to keep it high is because the developers made the terrible decision of making the colors all messed up when the health is low.
It's more annoying than the Zelda low heart announce sound - so you'll get the orbs, even if you probably could have used them later, just because the UI is now awful.

All in all, this game isn't worth the experience and the gameplay gets really old really fast.  I am glad I don't have to replay this.  
I think you should be glad if you never played it in the first place.  
And I'm kinda sad I have to write this out, because I know developing games is hard work and I know the developers tried - but it just didn't take.  
An admirable effort still falls flat - and this one did.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996368873', 'num_games_owned': 820, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 205, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1468026552}

author: {'steamid': '76561198154981104', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1643069222}
review:
I really wish I could recommend this game. Sadly, it breaks and glitches all too often.

I have a relatively good PC. Its meant for handling VR, 3D modeling, and server hosting, so it's equipped to handle tough graphics and processing. This game regularly drops frames and lags with nothing else open. Not only that, but the enemies break and stop moving, which stops progression of the game at level 4. Restarting the level, checkpoint, rebooting the game etc doesn't fix it. Validating the files won't fix it. I'm personally just stalled out there in the parasite nest "shortcut" area with no way to fix it so it will go again. 

I do have good things to say about the game! It's very cute and simple in a good way. The puzzles are elementary, but fun enough to solve. The music and art are both charming in their own way, and all of the areas have their own little theme going on. It has a lot of potential to be a great little game. They just desperately need to fix some playability and quality of life issues.

author: {'steamid': '76561198022024668', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 261, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 261, 'last_played': 1625134903}
review:
An interesting experience in a rather OK game.

Visual and graphic quality : 9/10. The graphic quality is good enough and I really love the artistic choices.

Music & Sound vibe : 10/10. The idea of each level starting with very few beats and slowly ramping up to the full tune while you progress into it is a trully cool idea. It really gives a special thing to the sound ambiance of this game and that's what's make it really enjoyable.

Gameplay : 8/10. Overall simple and efficient. You very quickly get the grasp of it and that's all what matters. I found the "skill" which makes you find hidden sounds (don't have the name in english sorry) a bit underused tho.

Game Design : 6/10.  I found the game design to be the weak point of this game. Nothing ruining it but sometimes it makes BeatBuddy a bit less enjoyable :
- There is plenty of time when the game design makes it that you have a split second to react, or miss some pink crystals because a vacuum plant or an event will forbid you from erh, swimming back? This result in a certain amount missed and at some point I was like, yeah, fuck the 100%. 
- The rhythm of the game is a big slow overall due to its puzzle nature. It tends to desync you with its core : beats, as you slow down and focus more on solving it rather than playing in rhythm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020012941', 'num_games_owned': 458, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1614130474}
review:
There are a couple of obstacles you need to dash through to the beat of the song, but don't be misled: THIS IS NOT A RHYTHM GAME.
It's also not a game that feels good to play. Or explore. I like these kinds of games and I was excited by the idea of one with rhythm elements, but this fell apart pretty quickly and stayed that way. 
I think the only part I really enjoy is dashing through those lines of bubbles on the beat, and even that can be finicky if you get a little too close to them out of your own full control.

N√£o tem o que fazer a partir da√≠, pois o jogo j√° gravou o lugar, s√≥ se voc√™ recome√ßar o jogo a partir do templo, o que te tira uns bons 20 minutos de jogo, √© meio meh, mas realmente me deixou chateado =(

author: {'steamid': '76561198218736355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 364, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1657376985}
review:
TLDR - It's a really good game with lots of innovation, but the mechanics take some work to get used to.

This game is a music based rhythm game with a minor focus on exploration. It has beautiful visuals, fantastic music, and it runs pretty well on weak hardware. But as for the gameplay, it's quality, but an acquired taste. I should start off by saying that this is a really unique game. Even amongst the niche genre of rhythm games, this game makes some innovative choices.

One example would definitely be the movement system of this game. It's not often that you see a rhythm game that doesn't streamline your choices into left/right, yes/no, now/later options. Most rhythm games are very binary/limited in their decision making. It's usually just pure timing as opposed to any dynamic decision making.

This game isn't like that - you traverse the world with full access to all 360 degrees of movement, but rhythm based. You can choose whatever direction you want and float along to the beat of the song. That's really rare, and it makes the game both freeing and difficult to control at the same time. The reason why most rhythm games force the player to make binary choices is because it is both easy to create (as a game developer) and easy to control (as a game player). And having control is integral for a rhythm game. If you get caught on a corner or accidentally misalign your direction, you may not land on the spot you need to be on time, and it can cause you to get punished in-game. This makes sense - a rhythm game is about being perfect, or getting punished for it. On paper, I don't have issues with this, even if there are some seemingly unfair punishments.

What I take issue with is that, your character is really floaty. Your character is underwater, so your not really walking or hopping to the beat, you are swimming to the beat, and that carries its own sense of momentum and weight that is not very easy to control. Imagine playing a 2d underwater level in some platformer, but the level focuses on sharp timing and aiming. Chances are, it would get frustrating quickly. But that's the thing - it all depends on what you are trying to do in this game. If you choose to do the basic path and don't try and dig around to find stuff, traversing the world isn't that hard, and you should get by relatively fine. However, if you dig around, you may find that the controls are holding you back from being able to have as much fun with this game.

Which leads to my second point about this games innovation - this a rhythm game with a healthy focus on exploration. That's definitely new to the genre, and the reason why they are able to do this so well is because of that 360 degree movement. Points should also be given to the beautiful art direction encouraging the player to look around certain areas of the map. Since you are able to go in any direction you want, you find yourself naturally exploring the level. And the game typically rewards exploration with a collectible shard that I haven't quite discovered its purpose yet, but I'm told it has value later on.

Yet another point to this games innovation is the level design - these levels are huge. I cannot emphasize that enough. Now, checkpoints are very frequent (<5 minutes apart), so you can quit out without losing much progress at all. More importantly, you don't really need to remember where stuff was before if you come back - all you need to remember is the game mechanics you learned near the beginning of that level. It really feels like the game is aware of how big the levels are, and intentionally plays with that in mind. But as I was saying, this is really innovative because, most rhythm games have levels that are confined within a small room (or on-rails levels like Beat Saber). Focusing on not just the timing of your presses, but where that is respective to something that is really far away can change the way you play this game compared to other rhythm games.

That more or less wraps up my thoughts on the games innovations. I know it was a lot, but I talked so much about it because I really feel like this game is worth purchasing if you're looking for something new. This game tries a lot of new things - most of it works, some of it not-so-much. But that's part of the fun of trying something new.

As for the rest of the game, I more or less voiced my thoughts in the beginning of this review. The only other thing I would add is that, while the levels of this game are fairly wide and open, the game itself is very much linear. There is usually only 1-2 ways to beat a level, though occasionally the game will let you be open ended about it (usually when you get inside a vehicle for parts of each level).

I would definitely recommend this game at full price if you are trying to find something new. This definitely fits the bill. On top of that, the music is fantastic, so I would encourage you to buy the soundtrack along with it. But if you just want a fun rhythm game, maybe wait for a sale, as the inconsistent maneuvering might get in the way of the fun.


UPDATE -- I forgot to add one other thing. There is one part of the game where something didn't load properly, so my character was stuck in the room with no way out (softlock). Thankfully, the frequent checkpoints meant that I only wasted about 5 minutes of my time. All the same, it is important that you know that softlocks exist, and they may occur once or twice in your playthrough.

UPDATE -- Ok, I have to take back a few things. When I wrote this review, I was more than halfway through the game, so I figured I was safe to give my thoughts. Well, I hate to say it, but the water physics start to become a pretty big problem once you get to a certain stage. Up until this point, precision maneuvering was only necessary for secrets/optionals, but once you reach this level, they start asking precision just to traverse the levels. I got through it, but that was officially too much to ask for. On top of that, I ran into yet another softlock. I still give my original verdict - if you are looking for something new, this is worth exploring, but now I really need to emphasize that this doesn't work very well as a rhythm game.

UPDATE - Finally beat the game. All in all, I would say it's worth my money, and thankfully, the final level made use of less annoying features than the second to last one did. In fact, the final level was a pretty good one to close on! Typically, I would consider replaying the game on whatever New Game+ option there was, but I won't even think about it for this game. I'm glad I got to experience it, but I don't plan to come back to this game unless I want something new again, or I'm looking for creative inspiration/guidance.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993208673', 'num_games_owned': 1780, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 383, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 383, 'last_played': 1491136844}
review:
The Good:
+ Early-to-Mid game the levels music is almost entirely produced by the enemies and objects in the environment!
+ Some good music with a beat that'll stick with you well after turning off the game.
+ Gameplay mechanics are for the most part fun and creative.

The Bad:
- Late game the environmental music is just there like any other game, and is no longer the product of enemies/objects.
- Gameplay starts to become a bit stale once new concepts stop being introduced.
- Story and characters lack any depth, and the incredibly brief and underwhelming ending does nothing to change this.
- Has known bugs with story dialog not appearing, and one bug which can cause a levels logic to completely break (softlock) requiring the level to be restarted from scratch.

Final thoughts:
Being a 'music-focused underwater puzzle action adventure' puts it in a unique position that there's really nothing else out there like it. It's a shame that the developers never fixed the various technical issues, but even with them this was one of the more enjoyable indie games I've played. I don't think it's worth the full asking price of $10, but at its typical sale price of $1-2 I'd definitely recommend checking it out.

([url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/39309883-Indie-Bullet-Point-Reviews/]Indie Bullet Point Reviews[/url])

author: {'steamid': '76561198022330965', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 202, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 202, 'last_played': 1606253292}
review:
This is a simple fun puzzle adventure game with the main premise being that everything moves to the beat of the music.  The highlight of this concept is how the music dynamically changes, with some enemies doing actions to the bass, or adding a high-hat to the music or shooting to a synth melody.  It's pretty neat and the music is good overall.  I could imagine it being a bit more catchy and responsive to what the player does, but it is pleasant. 

The game mostly consists of puzzles and avoiding/attacking enemies.  The puzzles aren't necessarily about keeping a beat or rhythm going, but more about navigating the environments as everything moves to a beat.  However you only have to be aware of this with enemies that you need to avoid.  Although I think there could be more player choices connected to the beat or rhythm, the puzzles are well designed and there's enough variety.

I did have fun with this and even chuckled at some well-written dialogue.  It is very easy and forgiving, which I actually did appreciate.  I died a few times, but there were generous checkpoints throughout which I was very grateful about.  The art looks good and level design is clear.  

Don't be put off by the menu, since I saw it and thought it was going to be lackluster.  It's a good game that lasts about 3 to 4 hours.

review:
Die Spielidee wirkt interessant und die verwendete Musik ist angenehm anzuh√∂ren.

Leider l√§uft das Spiel nicht gut, und die Umsetzung wirkt unvollendet.

Es ruckelt beim erreichen eines Save-Punktes und die Steuerung f√ºhlt sich ungelenk an.

Bei der Flucht vor dem gro√üen Fisch blieb ich an einer Stelle h√§ngen, worauf die Kamera ohne meine Spielfigur im Bild einfach den Rest der Sequenz abfuhr, und das Level f√ºr beendet erkl√§rte.

Danach habe ich es geschafft, das Tempel-Level in einen nicht l√∂sbaren Zustand zu buggen, dadurch dass ich in einem der Snare-Streams an der Wand h√§ngen blieb und starb.

Der Humor des Spiels kann mich leider auch nicht begeistern, und ich w√ºnschte mir, dass sich die Puzzles nicht so leicht durch gedankenloses Herumprobieren, sondern eher durch Nachdenken und Beobachten l√∂sen lie√üen.

review: Juego de plataformas con na ambientaci√≥n submarina y orientado a una sutil din√°mica de ritmo. El juego es visualmente bonito y la m√∫sica es buena (electr√≥nica con algunos toques de voz) pero la verdad es que el juego se vuelve muy mon√≥tono despu√©s de un rato. La jugabilidad no es muy buena, pues se derrapa demasiado el personaje que controlas, y a pesar de ser un mundo submarino creo que el movimiento tiene demasiado momento, lo cual hace que tratar de avanzar a mayor velocidad sea muy complicado y me forz√≥ a jugarlo m√°s lento. Adem√°s no hay mucho que puedas desbloquear en cuesti√≥n de mejoras o habilidades para el personaje. La progresi√≥n es lineal y b√°sicamente tienes que resolver peque√±os acertijos en una secci√≥n antes de avanzar a la siguiente, pero la ausencia e enemigos hacen que el mundo sienta medio vac√≠o. Para jugarlo una vez o para tratar de hacer speedrun creo que seria interesante pero no m√°s. Creo que es interesante y visualmente bien hecho, tiene una historia que sale sobrando y los personajes y sus personalidades son totalmente prescindibles pero ya. C√≥mpralo solo en oferta y trata de sacar los extras, que cuentan la historia de como el juego fue desarrollado que a mi parecer es infinitamente m√°s interesante que el juego

author: {'steamid': '76561198034883253', 'num_games_owned': 1004, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1587111389}
review:
While I can tell this is a high quality game it has too many small issues that bugged me so much I stopped playing. 

1. It's very tedious. I got to the 2nd world and was still doing the exact same types of puzzles as the 1st world.
2. When you die you lose any collected gems that you got after the checkpoint. This is especially annoying when there are lots of gems at a new checkpoint but you can only collect them after you have already reached the checkpoint meaning if you die you would need to spend another 10 seconds every death re-collecting the gems every time.
3. The music is just okay. Like, I don't hate it but it's not my favourite which makes it hard to enjoy the entire music aspect of the game.

If you can deal with issues like those and others then it really isn't that bad but as I've said in my other reviews, time is finite, and this game is most likely not worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990137628', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 255, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 184, 'last_played': 1588506967}
review:
It is hard to downvote a game that is doing a lot right but still does not manage to live up to my expecations. Mb I am pricker but there is some points and a conclusion in the end.

Pros in no particular order:
+ weird but nice story
+ great soundtrack
+ sweet yet simple graphics
+ responsive controls
+ beginner friendly

Cons in no particular order:
- feels like there is an ingame ad that constantly remind you of bying the soundtrack
- controls are responsive but yet bad: constant underwater physics and a stupid mixture of mouse and 1 (!) keyboard button
- since it is rythm based you either are good at it or not but "learning" rythm is kind of pointless
- ridles are on elementary school level
- no self zooming but stupid auto-zooming; this gets really annoying because there are several chase sections where the game zooms in very close to artificially increase the difficulty which I call poor level design; same problem occurs when you have to deliver the time bombs
- autosave system which cannot be redone so you loose some parts of the game (i. g. gems) because you cannot go back or you have to replay the whole section
- dialog boxes must be hit to be closed (no keyboard or fast click button)

Conclusion:
I do not like this one though it is done pretty well. It felt boring. And the zooming reminded me of the 90s where bad AIs simply cheated to increase difficulty.
If you are into music or rythm (i. g. guitar hero, singstar) and like an easy paced game this may be one for you.

review: A few decent hours of fun. Great art and soundtrack, gameplay a bit clunky at times. Some bugs exist, got stuck a few times in corners of the scenery. Very relaxing game overall, not that challenging of a rhythm game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143963837', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1501610528}
review:
El juego es una experiencia poco com√∫n pero muy disfrutable, se agradece que puedas no ir al ritmo: lo que a√±ade algo de dificultad. Eso si, si vienes buscando un juego complicado y largo, no esperes mucho, el juego no te va a durar m√°s de 8 horas.
El arte del juego es precioso (aunque parecer un poco b√°sico al comienzo) , y la m√∫sica merece suficiente la pena como para comprar el soundtrack.
PD: En las rebajas, el conjunto del juego junto a su banda sonora suele quedarse m√°s barato que el juego solo, aprovechen el ofert√≥n damas y caballeros.

author: {'steamid': '76561198796525887', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 844, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 135, 'last_played': 1584288776}
review: Beatbuddy is a really creative and intuitive music adventure game  it has tons of charm and heart that anyone could really play it and enjoy it

author: {'steamid': '76561197998739387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 398, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 398, 'last_played': 1561584537}
review: Its a shame that there are game breaking glitches like being unable to interact with things at certain points in the game because its otherwise a solid experience when on sale. The music is pretty addictive at points and they do a good job to very how the level's current tune sounds depending on the chapter you're at. If you can deal with a glitch or two, not a bad game at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966204189', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1553457410}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025876140', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 479, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 470, 'last_played': 1591325534}
review: Art is amazing, and the soundtrack is pretty great too, so it's very much a pleasant game world that I enjoy spending time in. Level design gets a little bit repetitive, though. For me it was one of those games that I would play for ~30 minutes and then do something else when I got tired of it, but I always came back again later until I finished it. It is a little buggy in places, so once or twice I actually had to start a level over since something had broken, but I got it really cheap on sale so I can't be too mad.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035662096', 'num_games_owned': 1269, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1551416343}
review: I really like what I've seen so far in this game, and I want to recommend it, but i can't. I loved levels 1-3, but part of level 4 just won't work for me, so I straight up can't continue the game at all. This isn't an issue for everyone, so I guess the game isn't totally unplayable for everyone, just me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043585027', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 235, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 235, 'last_played': 1550557197}
review:
I wanted to like Beatbuddy, but repeatedly throughout the game I noticed I wasn't having fun and was tiring over the same mechanic over and over. The mouse controls can be a little infuriating, so I switched over to keyboard, which was better but still had some issues. There were some issues with the checkpoints that made me have to reboot a few times. I wanted to go back and get all of the collectables, but if you miss even one little thing you have to go back through the entire level to get that 1 token you missed, not cool.

That being said, I liked the art style and the game story, although short, was good. The music is fun to listen to when the different creatures come on screen, but loops quite a bit.

I really hate to give a negative review, because I really wanted the game to be more enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095668425', 'num_games_owned': 203, 'num_reviews': 168, 'playtime_forever': 604, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 603, 'last_played': 1550095081}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018698098', 'num_games_owned': 604, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 387, 'last_played': 1547349080}
review: I made it to just before the last level where there is a boost pad, BUT IT DID NOT ACTIVATE, i travelled to a previous loading section and returned, didn't fix it. I loaded my last check point 5x, did not fix it. I closed the game and reopened it (twice), didn't fix it. I saw a video on Youtube and the boostpad worked instantly. I liked this game, but this was a GAME BREAKING bug that could not be fix. All that effort and time i spend went down the drain. Up till that point though, I did like the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016673781', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 342, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 342, 'last_played': 1546892593}
review: Cute and fun rhythmic puzzle adventure game, I enjoyed it, I only wish it could have been a little longer. The map rotation mechanics were crazy disorienting but I guess that's about it. Fun concept, wouldn't mind seeing more like it. It would have been neat if there were some cool and unique boss battles.

author: {'steamid': '76561198138016656', 'num_games_owned': 93, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 106, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1547441362}
review:
A very good rhythm based game.
- The atmosphere is artistic. 
- Good story telling technique.

Sadly I have too little time to explore more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11095, 'playtime_forever': 863, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1536751196}
review:
Beatbuddy is a 2D "platformer" (there's no platforming, swimming instead) with a minor shootemup component.   You control a blue blob on a quest to fix up what's wrong in his musical underwater world.  The various objects you interact with produce their own musical elements (snares, bass, hi-hats) which combine together in the game areas to produce music as you play, a little like Samorost 3. 

While I generally despise 2D platformers, this one is extremely well made, has a little voice acting, a wide range of PC graphics and control configuration options, a decent soundtrack and smooth, well polished gameplay, and a workable story. 

The $10 price tag is too high, but if you can get it on sale and you don't mind 2D games, this is one of the better ones, out of thousands on Steam.  I generally won't recommend these games to gamers but it'll get an "Informational" when I curate it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069330531', 'num_games_owned': 1508, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 388, 'last_played': 1531165661}
review:
This is a fun, casual rhythm based oceanic platformer with memorable music, quirky characters, and plenty of heart. The mechanics can get a little repetative,  along with puzzles that are almost too easy, but it's short, sweet, and fun. 

I'm surprised this game doesn't have more attention. It's not groundbreaking, but it is definitely a solid example of an indie platformer. The underwater mechanics are often done quite poorly in games like these, but Beatbuddy manages to make an all around smooth experience. My only issues with the controls were when trying to "fast swim." The turns became as wide as a schooner's radius, and hard to navigate some tight passages where dashing was quite necessary to get through. 

The puzzles are simple, and mostly based on rhythm. Getting through unharmed was quite difficult for me, but I am musically challenged. Luckily, there's plenty of healing items and checkpoints scattered throughout the game. Actually dying was a rarity, and when I did, I didn't lose much progress. This game may be too easy for most, so if you're seeking a challenge, this may be the wrong game for you. If you're looking for a family friendly game to play with a young, budding gamer, or if, like me, you find yourself in a mood where you just want to play a game without thinking too much or working too hard, this would be an excellent choice. 

The story is brief, and linear. It's more about gameplay here. I wish they had done a little more with the story, because the premise of the guardians of the world waking up, disrupting the very rhythm of everything, sounds quite a bit more dramatic and epic than "chase down the prince who is making this happen." It would have been quite the thrill to actually run into these guardians, and have a bit more of that backstory expanded. 

All in all, Threak did quite a nice job with their first full fledged game, and if they ever put out a Beatbuddy 2 with more focus on their universe, I'll be all over it. 

7/10 

P.S. Collecting the gems unlocks a behind the scenes "Making Of" slideshow of Threak from their very beginning. Well worth it, imo. Harkons back to the days where every game had unlockable concept arts and whatnot.

Liked this review? Follow my curator page by clicking the following link: 

https://steamcommunity.com/groups/diggingdeep#curation

author: {'steamid': '76561198131701503', 'num_games_owned': 242, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 362, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 362, 'last_played': 1525182668}
review:
[b]Beatbuddy[/b] is an enjoyable casual game.  Combined with it's original setting and impressive artistic design, it's a definite indie gem that I found pleasantly surprising.  It is perhaps a little short at 6 hours for a single playthrough, but even then I've seen plenty worse.  I'd say it's worth giving a try.

The gameplay is fairly simple.  There's exploration, some puzzles, and a few quasi-rhythm-game elements.  There are a number of collectables to find, but as best I can tell they only unlock extra art and background outside the main experience.  The puzzles are just hard enough to make you think, but still pretty easy.  The mostly involve figuring out how to open doors in the right order, or navigating mazes.

The rhythm-game aspects are most interesting, particularly as they also tie in to the setting.  Some obstacles can only be passed on the beat of the music; many enemies attack on the beat; some objects can only be interacted with in time to the music.  This helps build the world, one where music is the underlying fabric, and helps the excuse plot have more weight. 
 Finally, the art here is gorgeous.  The music, while not the type of stuff I usually like, also fits very well.  In all, I had fun, and you might too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005955224', 'num_games_owned': 305, 'num_reviews': 77, 'playtime_forever': 1343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1343, 'last_played': 1524738887}
review:
Weird game.
Solve the same puzzles for hours. Oh and hurry. There's a 'beat a game in 3 hours' achievement.
By the end of a game I got so dumb doing the same things so the very last puzzle of a [spoiler] drop a key in a spiky pipe[/spoiler] was solved only searching online. Cherry on top. Cool rewarding feelings. :-\
Some checkpoint bug threw me away without my car to a 'proceed in car only' place. Restart.
Want a perfect game? Unlock all the extras. Go search for every single gem. Watch it checking another fork on your road cause most likely you won't be allowed to come back. As a reward - devs photos. Bikini girls, I assume.
Barely made it for the first time. Two more to go. Scavenge run and speed run. I know it's gonna hurt.
Still, I don't give a beat.

author: {'steamid': '76561198052733586', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 61, 'last_played': 1523925576}
review:
[b] Stealing an idea I saw done here to help me get through my huge backlog of games on Steam. It is what I like to call my "1 Hour Playtime Reviews Because My Steam Library Has Gotten Stupid Big and I Don't Want to Regret How I Spend My Money Challenge." [/b] 

Beatbuddy is a music centric action 2D adventure game where the entire game takes place in everyones favorite style within the platforming genre. Underwater! 

Yes, yes, typically underwater controls leave a lot to be desired, but here, it all fits in an overall fun game with bouncy characters and chuckle worthy dialogue. There is a lot of charm here and I especially got a kick out of the music and how it played with level design. Also, as a long time fan of Parov Stelar's work, I was quite happy to his music in the first level.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075061111', 'num_games_owned': 1156, 'num_reviews': 211, 'playtime_forever': 287, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 287, 'last_played': 1523217924}
review:
8.4.2018. Game #31

[h1] I really thought I was going to love this game... [/h1]

I took one good look at this game and I said to myself: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm going to have a good time with this game‚Äù and I did, during the first level‚Ä¶ and after that first level I couldn‚Äôt have been happier when I saw those credits roll.

[h1] So, Beatbuddy: Tale of the Guardians? Sounds epic right? [/h1]

Beatbuddy: Tale of the Guardians is basically a swimming simulator with a few puzzles along the way and a neat twist that, unfortunately, gets old really fast. You play as the game as Beatbuddy, a cute little humanoid blob who is one of the three guardians of Symphonia (an underwater kingdom). Symphonia is, apparently, powered by music and music is generated through the three guardians who are always sleeping and dreaming of it. So after beatbuddy gets awoken by his sister, it‚Äôs clear that trouble is afoot. 

[h1] For a guardian, Beatbuddy sure doesn't look all that powerful [/h1]

While being a guardian of an underwater kingdom sounds like a powerful title, Beatbuddy sure doesn‚Äôt feel like a powerful guardian. In fact, he feels like a regular resident of symphony. Using his ‚Äúpowers‚Äù, beatbuddy must find what is causing a disturbance in the music, fix it and go back to sleep with his siblings, or at least, that‚Äôs how I understood the story. It‚Äôs not told very well. It starts well enough where you get this German-ish narrator who starts telling the lore and after a few lines, he goes quiet until the very end of the game, where he delivers the closing lines. What happened there? 

[h1] Easy controls and cute graphics [/h1]

The game looks pretty with its cartoon graphics. The controls are very easy to learn too. All you need is your mouse and occasionally the space key.

[h1] What do fish do? [/h1]

So, what is the gameplay like? Well, you control Beatbuddy with your mouse and you are trying to get from point A to point B through a 2D underwater levels. Like I said above, Beatbuddy can‚Äôt do much but swim and maybe dash. Later in the game, he learns how to attack but it barely feels like a power up since it doesn‚Äôt add much to the game. So what you do is, just like Dory from Finding Nemo says ‚ÄúJust keep swimming, just keep swimming‚Äù.

[h1] Move to the beat with some awesome tunes [/h1]

The neat twist this game has it the music. Every stage has a different song and the each level pretty much plays the song. So at first, you will only hear the most basic melody but then you will discover jump pads that add their own sounds to the song you are listening to, which enhances it. As you discover more things in the world, the song gets better. By the time I finished level 1 I was blown away. The level started with a catchy theme but as I kept going and finding things like crabs, jump pads, lasers and other stuff, the song kept getting more instruments and sounds. It‚Äôs truly a marvel. This is the case in each level too. The developers seem to be rather proud of their music as, even at the pause screen, you get the link to buy their soundtrack.

Unfortunately, having good music that improves as you keep going through the level is the only redeeming quality I found about beatbuddy. As much as I loved the first level, it because clear very soon that this was the only good thing the game has going for it. 

[h1] Music alone isn't enough to justify such a boring game [/h1]

Music aside, this game is just boring. You swim around, sometimes you solve a very basic puzzle, every other chapter you drive a submarine and the levels all look the same. The game never makes any daring attempts to spice up the gameplay and plays it very safe until the very end. Yes sure, you listen to some catchy tunes but they really don‚Äôt make up for the not so innovative gameplay.

Luckily, the game is kind of short. I managed to beat it in just under 5 hours but it‚Äôs possible to beat it in less than 3. Other than that, you have some gems that you can collect which unlock pictures of the developers goofing around in their office.

[h1] The music is nice but the game is boring [/h1]

My final rating: don‚Äôt play this game. Buy the soundtrack and play it while playing a better game that doesn‚Äôt have great music.

Next game: The Beginners Guide
https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198075061111/recommended/303210/

[h3]If you liked my review, feel free to follow my curator group. I‚Äôm trying to review every single game in my library. Seeing and interacting with fine folks, like you, keeps my motivation up. 
https://steamcommunity.com/groups/RevAMG [/h3]

review:
Eh, I dunno. This game's just kind of rubbish. The narrator is kind of annoying and I just didn't have very much fun playing it. I tried playing a few levels and it just really didn't click for me, in many ways this feels like a Flash game or something. It's not really a great looking game, and the gameplay never really excited me.

This is just a game that, you'd only play if you had nothing else to play, I think. The gaming market is just so saturated that little guys like this unfortunately barely come up on my radar because they're so small and in this case, not terribly exciting or fresh.

I'd rather just play like, ikachan or something. Now, that's a cute little fun game that's engaging and you don't even have to pay for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011816621', 'num_games_owned': 593, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 386, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 317, 'last_played': 1647164667}
review:
Beatbuddy is simply a little feel-good game. It's not that common that I like coming back to a game after a little break, but especially the music gave me fun and other positive feelings while playing so I looked foraward to finishing it. The fact that everything is a music based is a neat direction and I adore the art overall.

From my personal experience it's pretty forgiving and you actually don't need do be THAT rhythmic. It took a bit of time until I "got" the controls which is a bit rhythm based in some situations. Sometimes you fight things. It's pretty simple in a way that you just have to have some timing.

It was a couple times in bundles (I got it in one some years ago), but you can also get it for less than 2‚Ç¨ in a deal. I would say it's definitely worth it, if you like the music and the puzzles. 

Also the game worked flawlessly on Linux! yay!

author: {'steamid': '76561198025295316', 'num_games_owned': 1553, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 471, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 471, 'last_played': 1509822913}
review:
I feel kinda bad not recommending this game after completing 90% of the game. 

In this game you are some kind of musical thing that lives in a musical subterranean world where the prince is ruining things and kidnapping your musical sisters. By moving through stupid maps and completing boring and frustrating puzzles, you must save them. 

The worst thing is that, actually, the game starts being really funny and it could be a great platformer... However, 
 there are several reasons wich makes the game a 'meh' one. The most important ones, in my opinion:

* It sells itself as a 'musical platform' however rhythm doesn't have any kind of prominence.

* Controls are **NOT** responsive. It feels clunky and you'll die a lot of times because the response is slow and/or wrong. At least with mouse.

* It's repetitive. Despide the timing puzzle I can't pass, the rest of the game is basically the same puzzles over and over, being difficult by adding more frustrating elements, not clever ones. The game has a feeling of progress by "cheating" with more elements that will kill you thanks to the clumsy control of the thingy.


4/10 or something like that

author: {'steamid': '76561198046418282', 'num_games_owned': 888, 'num_reviews': 117, 'playtime_forever': 751, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 649, 'last_played': 1504781945}
review:
Dance-eJay music ?

Pros
- some story (save the princess :D)
- nice art and animation


Cons
- framerate up to 800 really drives the gpu up and
consumes allot of power and no way to stop not even
from the nVidia control panel, awful

- clunky menu system 

- beat based movement is way too annoying and cumbersome,
 just leave  me to go already, i have faster reactions
and button presses than this beat

- the constant zoom in and out
without player controlling it is horrible

- the scenery constantly getting in my way obstructing my vision,
 this is a side scroller but if i put myself into the character i
would be able to see forward and the sides, it's just unreal

- sometimes everything is falling apart and you are rushed this is
heavily forced upon the player at the end, suddenly gets harder
and the mechanics are interfering

- constant game breaking bugs at each chapter, have to restart
each time, i just stopped playing this game after each hour or two
because it got way too annoying to just start over because the game
suddenly stopped all the mechanics and you can't advance,
the game is effectively broken

- the annoying amateur beatboxing and half voice acted normally
half just gibberish is unacceptable, i stopped all the music and
sounds effectively rendering the mechanics of the beat based
gameplay useless, just played the game as a platformer and got
annoyed because the buttons didn't work when i pushed them,
the game started to feel as a bad platformer

- puzzles are very boring after a couple of hours, same ones
over and over, also carrying the keys from A to B on a timer and
sometimes because of the checkpoints the game gets you stuck
making you unable to get to the key again or unable to go back to
the point to bring the key so again restarting the chapter

- the music of the game reminded me when i was little i played
with a program called Dance eJay, just a fun music
making program but pretty generic sounds and music unless
you made your own samples, this game soundtrack is very generic

Note; it would be very hard to make the achievements for the
secrets that i haven't even found one and the completing of the
game under 3 hours would be horrible because of the chapter
bugs that would make you constantly restart them.

3/10 rating. Avoid this game even on a discount, unless they fix the
bugs, witch they won't because it's too old and they don't care.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978795694', 'num_games_owned': 383, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 382, 'last_played': 1502919148}
review:
Great arts and animations, solid gameplay with clever and never frustrating puzzles and funny action and time challenges and an outstanding OST, Beatbuddy is an indie game project who deserved many prizes and should be a good example for every newbie game developer. I loved that they put a short dev diary in the extras.

Only things that ruined me the magic were two gamebreaking bugs which made me restart the level and a bit of frustrations in "driving" sections due to not so great controls.

author: {'steamid': '76561197979812270', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 538, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 538, 'last_played': 1527254916}
review:
[h1]Beatbuddy: Tale of the Guardians[/h1]

Drei Hamburger Studenten gr√ºnden die Indieschmiede Threaks und ver√∂ffentlichen 2013 auf Steam Beatbuddy Tale of the Guardians. Das Spiel ist eine √§u√üerst gelungene Mischung aus Rythmus, Action und Puzzle Plattformer.

[h1]Story[/h1]

Die Geschichte ist schnell erz√§hlt. Es gibt unsere Spielfigur, den Beatbuddy, der im Unterwasser Reich Synfonia ein chilliges Leben zwischen Wasserbl√§schen, Krabben und Pflanzen zu f√ºhren scheint. Alles in Synfonia bewegt sich im Rythmus zur Musik und das ist nat√ºrlich elektronische Musik. Irgendwie f√ºhlt es sich an, als w√§re man in der Repeat-Schleife eines Disney Kino Titels gefangen. Alles, wirklich alles, hat den Beat in Synfonia. Jedes Objekt verursacht irgend einen Ton oder eine Melodie und alles zusammen ergibt die Musik. Aber eines Tages taucht ein B√∂sewicht auf, der alle nach seinen Bongos tanzen lassen will. Das wollen sich Beatbuddy und seine Freunde nat√ºrlich nicht gefallen lassen und so planen sie den B√∂sewicht zu sabotieren und seine Pl√§ne zu vereiteln.

Sonderlich viel Tiefgang ist hier nicht zu erwarten, aber wer w√ºrde einem Comic-Heftchen schon vorwerfen wollen, dass es ihm an und Bedeutsamkeit fehlt? Beatbuddy ist ein Spiel f√ºr Gelegenheitsspieler und die Zielgruppe sind eindeutig eher Kinder und Jugendliche. Einmal abgesehen davon ist das Spiel im Wesentlichen ein Plattformer und seit wann m√ºssen die unbedingt eine sensationelle Story haben? Die Geschichte ist kindgerecht und einigerma√üen witzig und charmant vorgetragen.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Das Gameplay in Beatbuddy Tale of the Guardians ist ein wenig speziell. Zun√§chst einmal befinden wir uns unter Wasser und die Steuerung ist bewusst ein wenig schwammig und tr√§ge, weil so √§hnlich w√ºrde man Bewegungen unter Wasser auch erwarten. Wer sich hier √ºber eine schwammige Steuerung beschwert, hat irgendwie nicht kapiert, was das Spiel abzubilden versucht. Nachdem man sich nach einer Weile an die Steuerung gew√∂hnt hat und mehr oder weniger ziellos durch die Level schwimmt, beginnt man ganz unweigerlich auch die Spielfigur im Rythmus der Musik zu bewegen. Das Spiel selbst beg√ºnstigt das, denn alles in Synfonia ist irgendwie leichter, wenn man es im richtigen Rythmus tut und unter Wasser kommt man am besten vorw√§rts, wenn man auf den Beat der Basedrum h√∂rt. Das wei√ü doch jedes Kind.

Wer Musik im Blut hat, dem wird dieses Spiel zufliegen. Wenn man auf die Musik h√∂rt, spielt es sich √ºber weite Strecken wie von selbst. Ein paar vereinzelte Puzzle oder auch der ein oder andere etwas gr√∂√üer geratene Levelabschnitt k√∂nnen erstmal verwirrend erscheinen, letztlich √ºberfordert einen Beatbuddy aber ganz sicher nicht, denn die L√∂sungen sind immer reichlich offensichtlich.

[h1]Grafik & Sound[/h1]

Sowohl die handgezeichneten und oft ziemlich bunten Levelhintergr√ºnde, als auch die Spielfiguren und Objekte im Spiel sind wirklich sch√∂n geworden. F√ºr mein Empfinden passt hier alles wunderbar zusammen.

Der Soundtrack ist eine klangvolle Reise durch das eher unbekannte Genre des Elektro Swing (& Funk). Hier kann Beatbuddy ganz gro√ü auftrumpfen. Verbl√ºffender Weise ist es den Entwicklern sogar gelungen, Parov Stelar, den Gottvater des Elektro Swing, f√ºr ihr Spiel zu begeistern und er hat direkt den Track f√ºr den ersten Level geliefert. Hut ab, hier kann man nicht nur ein ausgezeichnetes Gesp√ºr f√ºr Musik erkennen, sondern offenbar auch ein gutes H√§ndchen beim Verhandeln mit Musikern.

[h1]Kritik[/h1]

An einem Indie Titel rumzun√∂rgeln ist immer leicht. Solche Spiele sollte man nicht mit Triple-A Titeln vergleichen. Innerhalb seiner M√∂glichkeiten hat Beatbuddy wirklich ganze Arbeit geleistet und so will ich mich mit meiner Kritk auch mal ein wenig zur√ºckhalten.

√úber mehr als einen Schwierigkeitsgrad h√§tte mich schon gefreut, denn das ist die offensichtlichste Schwachstelle dieses Spiels. Mir war es ein wenig zu einfach und so manchem unmusikalischen Grundsch√ºler oder Puzzle Anf√§nger ist es vielleicht zu schwer. Auch der Wiederspielwert ist f√ºr mich ohne weitere Schwierigkeitsgrade so gut wie nicht vorhanden. Ein bi√üchen schade, denn so h√§tte man mit vergleichsweise wenig Aufwand deutlich mehr Spieler erreichen k√∂nnen, als mit dem Spinn-Off DLC "Beatbuddy on Tour", das ich komplett √ºberfl√ºssig finde.

Beatbuddy ist √ºberraschend leistungshungrig. Das m√ºsste vermutlich nicht sein. Mit einer etwas besseren Programmierung w√§re das bestimmt zu vermeiden gewesen.

[h1]Fazit[/h1]

Beatbuddy Tale of the Guardians ist ein Nischenspiel, das ich nicht unbedingt jedem empfehlen w√ºrde. Man sollte f√ºr das Genre Elekrto Swing oder elektronische Musik ganz generell empf√§nglich sein. Den Soundtrack findet man leicht auf youtube und √§hnlichen Internet Seiten. H√∂rt also ruhig mal rein, bevor ihr das Spiel kauft.

Man sollte auch etwas f√ºr leichte Puzzleplattformer √ºbrig haben, denn wer nur besonders schwere Spiele wie Flame Over und Geometry Dash mag, wird sich hier drei bis vier Stunden lang zu Tode langweilen.

Ich liebe diesen Soundtrack und so f√§llt es mir nicht schwer zu sagen, dass mir Beatbuddy gro√üen Spa√ü gemacht hat. Die Art und Weise wie hier Musikspiel und Puzzle Plattformer mit einer Unterwasserwelt verbunden wurden, ist ganz sicher etwas Besonderes. Ein Spiel wie Beatbuddy gibt es kein zweites mal und allein das ist schon ein gutes Kaufargument. Nachdem ich es mehr oder weniger am St√ºck durchgespielt habe, habe ich es ohne zu z√∂gern in die Liste meiner Indie Favoriten aufgenommen. 

Am meisten Spa√ü d√ºrfte jedoch die Zielgruppe der 5-12 J√§hrigen haben, denen man das Spiel mit gutem Gewissen schenken kann. Im Sale bekommt man es √ºbrigens f√ºr unter zwei Euro. Beatbuddy ist ganz klar ein Geheimtipp f√ºr gro√üe und kleine Musikliebhaber. Daumen hoch!

author: {'steamid': '76561197985754629', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 510, 'last_played': 1499176615}
review:
I wouldn't recommend this game even for the low price of 1,79‚Ç¨ as it's priced during this steam sale (2017). I got this game in a humble bundle for years ago but couldn't get myself to finish it until now for several reasons

Firstly, the good parts: The soundtrack. It's excellent, no doubt about it. Also the game got some rather nice backgorunds and coloring for the most part, The humor kind of works for the most parts and the "sound" the characters does is charming. The story serves it's purpose but not much beyond that. Everything else is a mess with this game.

Now for the bad parts: It got some real serious bugs. I had to restart chapters 4 times because some objects in the world wouldn't allow me to interact with it thus making me stuck. 3 of these instances happened during the last 2 chapters of the game. Also, sometimes the music wouldn't load which is kind of damning in a game which requires you to time dodges and attack with the music. 

The game have a tendency to introduce a mechanic and then repeat it and puzzles involving this mechanic for far to long which makes the mechanic overstay it's welcome and starts feeling rather tedious quickly, especially since the level designers never really plays around with it enough to make it very complicated. Also, the level layouts can be maze-like and very confusing from time to time.

The controls just doesn't feel good. It often feels like you have no real control over where you'll appear when you dodge and if a enemy (or you) will register a hit. I'm not sure if it's intentional or not, but also you'll later get a power-up that is for some strange reason bound to the same key as your attack which is annoying. The game claims that you can rebind your buttons but it wouldn't let me when I tried. Not sure if that's a problem with the game or with my gamepad setup though.

If you have any passing intrest of this game, I'd recommend you to buy the soundtrack and leave the game to the sidelines.
